sen.j: 鉄甲船（てっこうせん）とは、織田信長が九鬼嘉隆に命じて、毛利水軍・村上水軍に対抗するために建造させた大型の安宅船である。
sen.e: A tekkosen was a large-size Atake-bune (a type of naval warship) that Nobunaga ODA ordered Yoshitaka KUKI to build in order to fight against the Mori/Murakami navy.
A tekkosen was a large-size Atake-bune (a type of naval warship) that Nobunaga ODA ordered Yoshitaka KUKI to build in order to fight against the Mori/Murakami navy.
A tekkosen was a large-size Atake-bune (a type of naval warship) that Nobunaga ODA ordered Yoshitaka KUKI to build in order to fight against the Mori/Murakami navy.

sen.j: 村上水軍が得意とする焙烙火矢による攻撃に対抗するため、船全体を防火用の鉄板で覆ったものであったと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that the entire ship was covered with fireproof iron plates to prepare against attacks by horoku-hiya (one type of fire arrows) at which the Murakami navy was good.
It is said that the entire ship was covered with fireproof iron plates to prepare against attacks by horoku-hiya (one type of fire arrows) at which the Murakami navy was good.
It is said that the entire ship was covered with fireproof iron plates to prepare against attacks by horoku-hiya (one type of fire arrows) at which the Murakami navy was good.

sen.j: 実在には議論がある。
sen.e: Whether it really existed or not is under discussion.
Whether it really existed or not is under discussion.
Whether it really existed or not is under discussion.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 一説には大筒3門の他、大鉄砲を多数備え、船体に厚さ3mmの鉄板を鋲で貼り付けた長さ12～13間（21.8ｍ～23.6ｍ）、幅7間（12.7ｍ）の1500石積みの巨船といわれている。
sen.e: One theory says that it was a huge ship of 139 cubic meters in loading capacity with 21.8 to 23.6m in length and 12.7m in width, equipped with three ozutsu (Japanese artilleries) and many odeppo (big guns) and the surface of the body was tacked with iron plates 3mm in thickness.

One theory says that it was a huge ship of 139 cubic meters in loading capacity with 21.8 to 23.6m in length and 12.7m in width, equipped with three ozutsu (Japanese artilleries) and many odeppo (big guns) and the surface of the body was tacked with iron plates 3mm in thickness.

One theory says that it was a huge ship of 139 cubic meters in loading capacity with 21.8 to 23.6m in length and 12.7m in width, equipped with three ozutsu (Japanese artilleries) and many odeppo (big guns) and the surface of the body was tacked with iron plates 3mm in thickness.

sen.j: 別名大安宅船と言われる。
sen.e: It was also called a Big Atake-bune.
It was also called a Big Atake-bune.
It was also called a Big Atake-bune.

sen.j: 木津川の合戦に使われた船については信長公記、多聞院日記やオルガンティノの報告書などに記載が見られるが、寸法・装備などその実態については詳らかでない。
sen.e: Ships used in the battle of the Kizugawa river are described in Shinchoko-ki (Biography of the Warlord Oda Nobunaga), Tamonin nikki diary, Organtino's report and so on, but realities in detail such as its measurements/equipments are unknown.

Ships used in the battle of the Kizugawa river are described in Shinchoko-ki (Biography of the Warlord Oda Nobunaga), Tamonin nikki diary, Organtino's report and so on, but realities in detail such as its measurements/equipments are unknown.

Ships used in the battle of the Kizugawa river are described in Shinchoko-ki (Biography of the Warlord Oda Nobunaga), Tamonin nikki diary, Organtino's report and so on, but realities in detail such as its measurements/equipments are unknown.

sen.j: 信長公記やオルガンティノの報告書など当船について比較的詳細に述べられている資料には装甲についての記載がなく、鉄の装甲の実態については不明である。
sen.e: Even the data in Shinchoko-ki, Organtino's report and so on, which reported the ship comparatively in detail, included no description of the armor, so that it is unknown how the ship was armored with iron.

Even the data in Shinchoko-ki, Organtino's report and so on, which reported the ship comparatively in detail, included no description of the armor, so it is unknown how the ship was armored with iron.

Even the data in Shinchoko-ki, Organtino's report and so on, which reported the ship comparatively in detail, included no description of the armor, so it is unknown how the ship was armored with iron.

sen.j: 唯一多門院日記に伝聞として「鉄の船なり。鉄砲通らぬ用意敷儀なり」との記載があることが、同時代の資料において船体に鉄の装甲を施した船であると解釈できる部分である。
sen.e: Tamonin nikki diary alone reported it as "an iron ship that no bullets of a gun can pass through", which part can be interpreted in data of the same period that it was a ship whose hull was iron-covered.

Tamonin nikki diary alone reported it as "an iron ship that no bullets of a gun can pass through", which part can be interpreted that it was a ship whose hull was iron-covered in the light ofdocuments of the same period.
sen.cmt: 原文を、次の文とあわせて1つにしました。「同時代の資料において」は「同時代の資料に照らして」の意に解釈して修正。
sen.e: Tamonin nikki diary alone reported it as "an iron ship that no bullets of a gun can pass through", which part can be interpreted that it was a ship whose hull was iron-covered in the light ofdocuments of the same period.

sen.j: 宣教師グネッキ・ソルディ・オルガンティノはルイス・フロイス宛の報告書の中で「王国（ポルトガル）の船にも似ており、このような船が日本で造られていることは驚きだ」と述べている。
sen.e: Gnecchi-Soldo Organtino, a missionary, wrote in his report to Luis Fois that the ship was like one in the Kingdom (Portugal) and that he was surprised to know that such a ship had been constructed in Japan.

Gnecchi-Soldo Organtino, a missionary, wrote in his report to Luis Frois that the ship was like one in the Kingdom (Portugal) and that he was surprised to know that such a ship had been constructed in Japan.
sen.cmt: Froisにスペルを修正しました。
sen.e: Gnecchi-Soldo Organtino, a missionary, wrote in his report to Luis Frois that the ship was like one in the Kingdom (Portugal) and that he was surprised to know that such a ship had been constructed in Japan.

sen.j: 海上封鎖のバリケードとして織田信長の命で九鬼嘉隆により伊勢で6隻建造され、大阪湾へ向う途上に雑賀・谷輪の水軍と戦いこれを破り、第二次木津川口の戦いにおいてはたった6隻で600隻もの毛利水軍の船団を壊滅させたといわれている。
sen.e: Six ships were built in Ise for sea barricades by Yoshitaka KUKi, who was ordered by Nobunaga ODA: it is said that the Oda navy with these ships, on the way to Osaka Bay, defeated the Saiga/Taniwa navy, and also destroyed 600 ships of the Mori navy fleet only with six ships.

Six ships were built in Ise for sea barricades by Yoshitaka Kuki, who was ordered by Nobunaga Oda； it is said that the Oda navy with these ships, on the way to Osaka Bay, defeated the Saiga/Taniwa navy, and also destroyed 600 ships of the Mori navy fleet only with six ships.

Six ships were built in Ise for sea barricades by Yoshitaka Kuki, who was ordered by Nobunaga Oda； it is said that the Oda navy with these ships, on the way to Osaka Bay, defeated the Saiga/Taniwa navy, and also destroyed 600 ships of the Mori navy fleet only with six ships.

sen.j: これは嘉隆の志摩の荒い海で鍛えられた操縦のため。
sen.e: This owed the steering of Yoshitake, who trained himself in the rough sea of Ise.
This could be attributed to the steering of Yoshitake, who trained himself in the rough sea of Ise.
This could be attributed to the steering of Yoshitake, who trained himself in the rough sea of Ise.

sen.j: 信長の死後は大阪湾に投錨したまま放棄され、朽ちていったと言う話と解体されて数隻の小早等に作り直された話等も伝わっている。
sen.e: Legend says that after Nobunagsa's death they were anchored in Osaka Bay, and left until it went rotten, or they were dismantled into several small ships.
Legends say that after Nobunaga's death, they were anchored in Osaka Bay and left until it went rotten, or they were dismantled into several small ships.
Legends say that after Nobunaga's death, they were anchored in Osaka Bay and left until it went rotten, or they were dismantled into several small ships.

sen.j: 、徳川秀忠が幕府御船手頭向井忠勝に建造させた史上最大級の安宅船「安宅丸」は、総櫓及び船体の総てに防火・防蝕を目的とした銅板貼りが施されていた事が幕府の公式な記録から確認されており、1635年当時、軍船の表面に金属板を貼るという発想が存在していた事そのものは疑いがたい事実と言えよう。
sen.e: From the official bakufu documents it is confirmed that the "Atake Maru", the largest Ataka bune in history, which Hidetada TOKUGAWA ordered Tadakatsu MUKAI, the chief of the bakufu navy to build, had all oars and the whole hull covered with copper plates for the prevention of fire and erosion, which proves a definite fact that an idea of covering the surface of a warship existed in 1635.

From the official bakufu documents it is confirmed that the "Atake Maru", the largest Ataka bune in history, which Hidetada TOKUGAWA ordered Tadakatsu MUKAI, the chief of the bakufu navy to build, had all oars and the whole hull covered with copper plates for the prevention of fire and erosion, which proves a definite fact that an idea of covering the surface of a warship existed in 1635.

From the official bakufu documents it is confirmed that the "Atake Maru", the largest Ataka bune in history, which Hidetada TOKUGAWA ordered Tadakatsu MUKAI, the chief of the bakufu navy to build, had all oars and the whole hull covered with copper plates for the prevention of fire and erosion, which proves a definite fact that an idea of covering the surface of a warship existed in 1635.

sen.j: また天正元年（1573年）には琵琶湖湖畔の佐和山において、丹羽長秀の指揮のもと、長さ三十間（約55m）幅７間（約１３ｍ）櫓百挺立て、軸櫓に矢倉を設けた大船が建造された例が存在する（信長公記より）。
sen.e: There exists another example that a large ship, which was about 55m in length, about 13m in width, and equipped with 100 oars, was built in Sawayama, the lake side of Biwako Lake in 1573 on the command of Nagahide NIWA (from Shincho-koki).

There exists another example that a large ship, which was about 55m in length, about 13m in width, and equipped with 100 oars and a watchtower on 軸櫓, was built in Sawayama, the lake side of Biwako Lake in 1573 on the command of Nagahide NIWA (from Shincho-koki).
sen.cmt: 「軸櫓に矢倉を設けた」訳抜け。「軸櫓」読み方意味不明のため、漢字のまま表記しました。意味解釈が困難なため訳出できず
sen.e: There exists another example that a large ship, which was about 55m in length, about 13m in width, and equipped with 100 oars and watchtowers at the bow and the stern, was built in Sawayama, the lake side of Biwako Lake in 1573 on the order of Nagahide NIWA (from Shincho-koki).
sen.cmt: 軸櫓＝•舳艫(じくろ)「船首と船尾」のようですので、そのように訳しました。軸櫓→watchtowers at the bow and the sterncommand → order

sen.j: 擬装は安土城を手がけた城大工、岡部又右衛門が担当した。
sen.e: The camouflage was made by Mataemon OKABE, a castle carpenter, who took charge of Azuchi Castle.
The camouflage was made by Mataemon OKABE, a castle carpenter, who took charge of Azuchi Castle.
The camouflage was made by Mataemon OKABE, a castle carpenter, who took charge of Azuchi Castle.

sen.j: 大津か坂本との間を京洛への往来に用いていたという。
sen.e: It is said to have been used for the traffic to Kyoto from Otsu or Sakamoto.
The ship is said to have been used for the traffic to Kyoto from Otsu or Sakamoto.
sen.cmt: 主語(It) が何を指すのか分かりにくいので"The ship"としました。
sen.e: The ship is said to have been used for the traffic to Kyoto from Otsu or Sakamoto.

sen.j: この船が鉄板張りであったか否かは定かでない。
sen.e: It is not certain whether this ship was an iron plated one.
It is not certain whether this ship was an iron plated one.
It is not certain whether this ship was an iron plated one.

sen.j: 後年、九鬼家は伊勢の大湊 (伊勢市)において、鉄甲船とほぼ同水準とみられる安宅船を建造し「鬼宿（おにやど）」と名付けたが、この船の威容をいたく気に入った豊臣秀吉は、文禄・慶長の役の際の旗船としてこれを採用し、旗船の証である茜の吹流しと金団扇の馬印を授け、船名も「日本丸（にっぽんまる）」と改称させた。
sen.e: In later years the Kuki family in Ominato (Ise City) in Ise built an Atake-bune on a level with a tekkosen and named ""Oniyado", and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who liked the magnificence of the ship, adopted it as a flag ship in the Bunroku-keicho War, put on it a windswept style madder flag and an Uma-jirushi (commander's flag) of a golden fan, which were a token of a flag ship, and renamed it "Nippon Maru".

In later years the Kuki family in Ominato (Ise City) in Ise built an Atake-bune virtually equivalent to a tekkosen and named ""Oniyado", and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who liked the magnificence of the ship, adopted it as a flag ship in the Bunroku-keicho War, put a madder streamer and an Uma-jirushi (commander's flag) of a golden fan on it as a token of a flag ship, and renamed it "Nippon Maru".
sen.cmt: 「同水準」"on a level with"→"equivalent to"に修正しました。「吹流し」"windswept style"→"streamer"に修正しました。
sen.e: In later years the Kuki family in Ominato (Ise City) in Ise built an Atake-bune virtually equivalent to a tekkosen and named ""Oniyado", and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who liked the magnificence of the ship, adopted it as a flag ship in the Bunroku-keicho War, put a madder streamer and an Uma-jirushi (commander's flag) of a golden fan on it as a token of a flag ship, and renamed it "Nippon Maru".

sen.j: 1500石積、長さ34m、幅9.5m、乗員180人、櫓100挺立てであったと言われる。
sen.e: The ship is said to have been 1500 koku (139 cubic meters) in loading capacity, 34m in length, 95m in width, had a capacity of 180 crew members and was equipped with 100 oars.
The ship is said to have been 1500 koku (139 cubic meters) in loading capacity, 34m in length, 9.5m in width, had a capacity of 180 crew members and was equipped with 100 oars.
The ship is said to have been 1500 koku (139 cubic meters) in loading capacity, 34m in length, 9.5m in width, had a capacity of 180 crew members and was equipped with 100 oars.

sen.j: 日本丸は江戸時代に入った後も現役の軍船として就役していたが、500石積み60挺立の船に縮小改造され、「大竜丸」と、改名を重ねる事になった。
sen.e: The Nippom Maru was put into commission as an active-duty warship in the early Edo period, however, it was remodeled into a smaller ship with 500 koku (139 cubic meters) in loading capacity and 60 oars, and again renamed "Dairyu Maru".

The Nippon Maru was put into commission as an active-duty warship in the early Edo period, but it was remodeled into a smaller ship with 500 koku (139 cubic meters) in loading capacity and 60 oars, and again renamed "Dairyu Maru".

The Nippon Maru was put into commission as an active-duty warship in the early Edo period, but it was remodeled into a smaller ship with 500 koku (139 cubic meters) in loading capacity and 60 oars, and again renamed "Dairyu Maru".

sen.j: 「大竜丸」となった後は、新たに竜頭の彫刻が船首に追加されていたという。
sen.e: It is said that after it was named "Dairyu Maru", a sculpture of a dragon head was newly added to its prow.
It is said that after it was named "Dairyu Maru", a sculpture of a dragon head was newly added to its prow.
It is said that after it was named "Dairyu Maru", a sculpture of a dragon head was newly added to its prow.

sen.j: 前述の通り、1635年、江戸幕府は史上最大の安宅船である安宅丸を建造し、鉄甲船と同様の考えから銅板を貼っている。
sen.e: As mentioned above, the Edo bakufu built the Ataka Maru, the largest Ataka-bune in history which was covered with copper plates based on same idea as a tekkosen.
As mentioned above, the Edo bakufu built the Atake Maru, the largest Atake-bune in history which was covered with copper plates based on the same idea as a tekkosen.
As mentioned above, the Edo bakufu built the Atake Maru, the largest Atake-bune in history which was covered with copper plates based on the same idea as a tekkosen.

sen.j: 鉄板では海水によって腐食するため長期の運用は不可能であり、そのため銅板に換えたと考えられ、鉄甲船からの順当な発展型と言える。
sen.e: Iron plates would become eroded so easily by sea water that they were unfit or a long-term use, therefore, they were substituted by copper plates, which can be said to have made a reasonable development from a tekkosen.

Iron plates would become eroded so easily by sea water that they were unfit for a long-term use, therefore, they were substituted by copper plates, which can be said to have made a reasonable development from a tekkosen.

Iron plates would become eroded so easily by sea water that they were unfit for a long-term use, therefore, they were substituted by copper plates, which can be said to have made a reasonable development from a tekkosen.

sen.j: しかしながら幕府の財政難により1682年に解体されてしまい、鉄甲船の系譜はこれで途絶える事となった。
sen.e: However, it was dismantled in 1682 due to financial difficulties of the bakufu, leading to the end of tekkosen line ships.
However, it was dismantled in 1682 due to financial difficulties of the bakufu, leading to the end of tekkosen line ships.
However, it was dismantled in 1682 due to financial difficulties of the bakufu, leading to the end of tekkosen line ships.

tit.j: 鉄甲船にまつわる疑問点

sen.j: 鉄甲船の動力は通常の安宅船と同じく櫓、および起倒式の木綿帆によるものと推定されているが、鉄板によって重量を増した船がこの方式で実用に耐えうる速度で航行できるかは不明である。
sen.e: It is estimated that the power of a tekkosen, like ordinary Atake-bune, came from oars and retractable cotton sails, however, it is unclear that a ship which gained weight due to iron plates could run in this method at a practical speed.

It is estimated that the power of a tekkosen, like ordinary Atake-bune, came from oars and retractable cotton sails, but it is unclear whether a ship with more weight due to iron plates could run at a practical speed using this method.

It is estimated that the power of a tekkosen, like ordinary Atake-bune, came from oars and retractable cotton sails, but it is unclear whether a ship with more weight due to iron plates could run at a practical speed using this method.

sen.j: 伊勢から熊野灘を経由して大阪湾に回航しているが、鉄板でトップヘビーになった船が波の荒い熊野灘を通り抜け出来るのかどうか疑問視する声もある。
sen.e: It doubled Osaka Bay via the Kumano-nada Sea from Ise, some people doubt that a ship that became extremely heavy because of iron plates could pass through the rough Kumano-nada Sea.
Although it navigated to Osaka Bay via the Kumano-nada Sea from Ise, some people doubt that a ship that was extremely heavy because of iron plates could pass through the rough Kumano-nada Sea.
Although it navigated to Osaka Bay via the Kumano-nada Sea from Ise, some people doubt that a ship that was extremely heavy because of iron plates could pass through the rough Kumano-nada Sea.

sen.j: 実際に木津川をこの6隻を主力として封鎖できたかも不明である。
sen.e: It is also uncertain whether the blockade of the Kizu-gawa River was really possible with these six ships as main force.
It is also uncertain whether the blockade of the Kizu-gawa River was really possible with these six ships as main force.
It is also uncertain whether the blockade of the Kizu-gawa River was really possible with these six ships as main force.

sen.j: 第二次木津川口の戦いで敗北した毛利水軍であったが、翌年には三木城へ兵糧を運び入れる等、活発な活動を見せており、信長公記に見られるような一方的大勝利であったかも疑問とされている。
sen.e: The Mori navy, which was defeated in the second battle of Kizugawaguchi, started active movements such as carrying army provisions into Miki-jo Castle the next year, which makes the runaway victory recorded in Shincho koki doubtful.

The Mori navy, which was defeated in the second battle of Kizugawaguchi, started active movements such as carrying army provisions into Miki-jo Castle the next year, which makes the runaway victory recorded in Shincho koki doubtful.

The Mori navy, which was defeated in the second battle of Kizugawaguchi, started active movements such as carrying army provisions into Miki-jo Castle the next year, which makes the runaway victory recorded in Shincho koki doubtful.
